awd_titl_txt: OP: Quantum Phases and Dynamics of Bose-Einstein Condensates with Artificial Gauge Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates fundamental laws of nature predicted by quantum mechanics, one of the cornerstones of modern physics. The predictions of quantum mechanics are very counterintuitive and unfamiliar compared to the experiences of everyday life, but they play a dominant role when spatial dimensions get small, e.g. at length scales reached using modern nanofabrication or computer chip fabrication techniques, and on atomic scales. Conducting experiments on the nanoscopic length scale poses severe technical difficulties, but an alternative approach exists: the same laws of quantum mechanics can also be studied when a gas of atoms is cooled down to temperatures near absolute zero. At these temperatures, fundamental quantum lengths become larger and details about these ultracold quantum gases can be imaged in a custom microscope, allowing their properties to be examined in very flexible ways using tools from the realm of atomic physics. The particular predictions investigated in this project concern a property called spin-orbit coupling. In the vast majority of existing electronic devices, the transport of electrically charged particles (i.e., electrons) is exploited to perform a device function. However, electrons have an additional property called spin, which can be pictured as a fast spinning motion akin to that of a spinning top. The orientation of this rotation can also be used to perform a device function, leading to "spintronic" devices. Spin-orbit coupling denotes an interplay between this spinning motion and the linear flow of particles that constitutes a conventional current. It is the basic building block of many proposed future devices and of advanced materials with exotic properties. The underlying physics are rather complex, and the experiments of this project provide an important test bed with which new concepts are explored. 
 
Over the recent years, immersing ultracold atoms into suitably tailored laser beams has emerged as a powerful tool to investigate  quantum dynamics. The different hyperfine states coupled by the lasers can be considered orientations of a "pseudo" spin, so that absorption and emission of a photon constitutes a spin flip. At the same time, due to momentum conservation, the atom's motion is changed when a photon is absorbed or emitted. As a result, the pseudospin and the motion of an atom become coupled in a laser-driven transition, in analogy to spin-orbit coupling known from condensed matter physics. A suitable dressing of atoms with laser light can also lead to artificial gauge fields and artificial magnetic and electric fields, so that charged-particle behavior can be investigated with neutral atomic quantum gases. Furthermore, the dispersion relation of the atoms can be modified to exhibit intriguing double-well structures showing roton-like minima.  Over the previous grant period, such techniques have been applied to a rubidium Bose-Einstein condensate to investigate quantum phases and quantum dynamics in spin-orbit coupled condensates.  Capitalizing on the insights gained and technological developments performed in the previous grant period, this project will explore new frontiers that challenge current theoretical descriptions. Aspects include novel quantum phases induced by spin-orbit coupling and by the interplay with optical lattices, as well as the dynamics of solitons in a spin-orbit coupled environment and topological structures in higher dimensions.

por.por_cntn:
The focus of this project has been the investigation of  novel phases and dynamics in systems of ultracold atoms. When cooling a cloud of atoms to temperatures near absolute zero, the system enters the realm of quantum mechanics where the laws of nature are very different from those of the classical world. Exploiting quantum mechanics for the development of advanced quantum technologies requires are precise understanding of the underlying principles.  Ultracold atoms are a very powerful and flexible testbed with which quantum mechanics can be probed.  In this project, ultracold atoms have been immersed into suitably tailored laser fields to investigate their dynamics. This laser dressing of the atoms leads to a range of intricate effects, including artificial magnetic and electric fields and modified dispersions. As a particularly striking example, we have studied the dynamics in a region of negative effective mass: in this region, an atom pushed forward by a force slows down, rather than being accelerated. This counterintuitive behavior has directly been observed in our experiments, and our publication on this topic has been met with such widespread interest that it has even been reported in international news channels. The techniques developed in the frame of this project have opened the door to many further studies addressing, e.g., the nature of quantum shocks and the emergence of effective viscosity in quantum mechanical flow.

This project has been an important training ground for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs at Washington State University. To give just two outstanding examples, an undergraduate student who previously had received a Berry M. Goldwater Scholarship, graduated summa cum laude with results obtained in our lab. He was awarded a Fulbright scholarship with which he continued in this field of study in a group at the University of Heidelberg, Germany, for one year. He is now a PhD student at NIST, Boulder. A female graduate student who performed her graduate research in our group received her PhD degree in 2019 and is now the Clare Boothe Luce Assistant Professor of Physics at the University of San Diego, where she continues to advocate for science, educates the next generation of students, and performs research. Members of our group have been involved in numerous outreach activities throughout the duration of this project, most notably in the organization of a three day long 2020 APS CUWiP (Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics) conference and a Northwest Quantum Nexus workshop, both of which were held at Washington State University.
